group.name: BruJUG - The Brussels Java User Group

description:
Hi everyone!

It took some time to set things up, but here we go, the[masked] season is officially launched!

We would like to thank the ESI professors who kindly proposed to host this event in their premises. Kudos to them!

And remember, after the talk, we will find a nice bar with those who want to join to continue the discussion, or just do networking.

So, without further ado, here is the abstract:

Caching: principles and features, in Ehcache and JSR-107

The goal of this talk is to discuss caching in an application, why and when to use it but also when not to.

From this base we will move to discuss features that are common enough that they ended up in JSR-107, and discuss the matching ones in Ehcache.

Then we will look around at different features that can be found in Ehcache, from the open-source version up to the Terracotta clustered one.

To spice up the presentation, we will side track into technical details or design dilemma to illustrate the not so quiet life of an open-source project.
how_to_find_us: The event will take place in the small auditorium at the ESI. Just follow the posters when you arrive there.
name: "Caching: principles and features, in Ehcache and JSR-107" by Louis Jacomet

group.name: BruJUG - The Brussels Java User Group

description:
Hi everyone!

We hope you spend a great holiday season and that you are fully ready for this new year.

Although a bit too late for 2013, our next speaker, Andy Petrella, has a gift for you, an advent calendar full of Scala! We are pretty sure you'll like it.

We would like to thank again the professors at the ESI institute who did accept to host our previous session, this one, and the coming ones in their premises.

And remember, after the talk, we will find a nice bar with those who want to join to continue the discussion, or just do networking.

So, without further ado, here is the abstract:

Scala Claus' Advent Calendar

An interactive talk aiming to introduce 25 concepts of Scala in a very concrete and pragmatic way.

The goal of this talk is to democratize Scala and to annihilate its reputation to be hard...

For that, we'll follow a funny path, materialized in the form of a Advent Calendar involving a cool and tasty suprise every new day until XMas.
how_to_find_us: The event will take place in the small auditorium at the ESI. Just follow the posters when you arrive there.
name: "Scala Claus' Advent Calendar" by Andy Petrella

group.name: BruJUG - The Brussels Java User Group

description:
What does developers hate more than chasing bugs? Chasing bugs in legacy software.

So called legacy software is the daily nightmare of way too many developers. How comes a piece of code can evolve in such a strange beast that everybody is afraid to touch? And more importantly, what can we do to prevent our software to become the legacy software of the future?

Olivier Gaudin, CEO of SonarSource surely has some interesting proposal to solve this issue. Join us to learn more!

For the speaker's bio and abstract of the talk, see our Wiki...
name: Continuous Inspection with SonarQube

group.name: BruJUG - The Brussels Java User Group

description:
Joint venture event with BeJUG and WaJUG. Free event.


VERY IMPORTANT:

REGISTRATION MUST BE DONE VIA EVENTBRITE. ONLY 100 SEATS AVAILABLE.

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/from-iterable-to-lambdas-streams-and-collections-tickets-10188924347?aff=eorg

From Iterable to Lambdas, streams and collections

With no doubt, the most widely used API of the JDK is the Collection API. Brilliantly designed 15 years ago, it is still at the core of all the Java applications. In 2004 if underwent its first refactoring with the introduction of the generics. This refactoring did not change the collections patterns. With the introduction of lambda expressions in JDK 8, the collection API is again rewritten, but this time the situation is different : the patterns are completely changed.

The first part of this session introduces the lambda expressions, how we can write them, and what they bring to us developers. The second part presents in details the new patterns introduced by the Stream and Collector APIs. These new APIs will change the way we process large collections content, enabling concurrent and parallel access, with a very simple programming model, and amazing patterns. Complex examples will show how powerful those APIs are, and how they can help us write efficient and clean code.

Jose Paumard

José is an assistant professor at the Institut Galilée (Université Paris 13) and a PhD in applied mathematics from the ENS de Cachan. He has discovered the Java language in 1995, and has been teaching the Java technologies at the university since 2000.

José has also been working as an independant for numerous companies, in a variety of areas. He is a well known Java / Java EE expert and trainer. He also publishes "Java le soir", a technical blog in french (http://blog.paumard.org/), with about 750 pages of courses about Java / JEE in open access.

He is a member of the french Paris Java User Group, and co-organizer of Devoxx France.

Date & Location

March 25th from 19h00 til 21h00 in Leuven

venue.name: KUL room C300 00.81 - Instituut voor Mechanica

name: From Iterable to Lambdas, streams and collections

group.name: BruJUG - The Brussels Java User Group

description:
Remember AWT? Swing? The endless battle between pro and anti-SWT? Well that's old days. 

There is a new kid in town for client-side java application: Java FX. Join us to learn more about it.

Because Java is more than a backend language.

Abstract

Java client applications provide a great alternative for web-based applications to Java developers.

Using JavaFX, you can leverage your existing Java skills and build state-of-the art applications that run on desktop, embedded, mobile and tablets.
In this session, we will give an overview of the JavaFX platform, and show how it can be used to create client applications that combine a nice UI with an easy connection to web services and that are also cross-platform .

Speaker

Johan Vos started to work with Java in 1995.  He was part of the Blackdown team helping port Java to Linux.  With LodgON, the company he co-founded, he is mainly working on Java based solutions for social networking software.

Because he can't make a choice between embedded development and enterprise development, his main focus is on end-to-end Java, combining the strengths of back-end systems and embedded devices. His favourite technologies are  currently Java EE / Glassfish at the backend and JavaFX at the front-end.

Johan is a Java Champion, a member of the BeJUG steering group, the Devoxx steering group and he is a JCP member. He is a co-author of the Pro JavaFX 2 book, and he has been a speaker at numerous conferences on Java (including JavaOne and Devoxx). You can read his blog at http://blogs.lodgon.com/johan and follow his tweets at http://twitter.com/johanvos.
name: Discover what JavaFX has to offer

group.name: BruJUG - The Brussels Java User Group

description:
Hi everybody!

It is our pleasure to invite you to our last session for the[masked] season. Don't miss this one as you'll have to wait for 3 months before the next one. Plus the topic is interesting! Check it out:

Abstract:

Java Enterprise Edition is unarguably the most widely used open, standard based, platform for developing and deploying enterprise applications.

This 'Java EE State of the Union' session will gives you a technical overview of Java EE 7 which has been finalised and released just one year ago. We will also spend some time on discussing the future of the platform, i.e. Java EE 8 :

- what are the themes and what can we expect in Java EE 8
- the Java EE 8 roadmap
- how you and the BruJUG can contribute to Java EE 8, etc.

We will also share some technical thoughts and glimpses on some of the APIs that will evolve in Java EE 8.

About the speaker:

David Delabassee is a Java EE / GlassFish evangelist working for Oracle. 

Prior to Oracle, David spent a decade at Sun Microsystems focusing on Java end-to-end (from the smart card to the high end server), related technologies and the developer tools.
In his various roles, David has been involved in numerous Java projects since the early days of this technology. 

David lives in Belgium and in his spare time, he enjoy tinkering and playing with technologies such as Java, Arduino, Linux, Home Automation, etc. 

You can follow David on Twitter under @delabassee
name: Java EE 7, Java EE 8 and possibly the Red Devils!

group.name: BruJUG - The Brussels Java User Group

description:
The[masked] season is now OPEN!

Hi everyone,

We hope you had time for some great holidays during this summer and that your are now fully charged for a new round.

Our first meeting  for this season has some interesting materials as you'll discover below. We hope to see you numerous there, and don't forget to spread the news in your office, to your friends and, if you cannot attend, to your enemies!

Have a nice day,
The BruJUG team.

Speaker

Geoffrey De Smet

Abstract

The world is full of planning problems. Whether your company is scheduling employees to shifts, delivery routes to vehicles, aircraft/crews to flights, courses to timeslots/rooms, manufacturing jobs to machines, you want optimize those schedules:

• fulfill all your business needs, adhere to all constraints;

• minimize cost, maximize profit; 

• maximize customer satisfaction, maximize employee happiness

And you need to respond in real-time with the best planning as circumstances change - equipment breaks, the weather changes or staff call in sick.

Which algorithms can we use to optimize these use cases? How do those algorithms work? How do we scale out? And how much does this reduce our company’s expenses (and ecological footprint)?

OptaPlanner is an open source, lightweight, embeddable planning engine written in Java. It helps normal Java programmers solve constraint satisfaction problems efficiently. Under the hood, it combines optimization heuristics and metaheuristics with very efficient score calculation. For more information, see www.optaplanner.org.
name: OptaPlanner: Optimizing vehicle routes, shift rosters and other NP-hard problems

group.name: BruJUG - The Brussels Java User Group

description:
Hello everybody!

Ever had to store and manipulate a lot of data? Ever feel like RDBMS would not be the perfect match for your task? Well, Facebook had that problem too. And from that was born a new project that gained some traction and became open source: Cassandra.

Since its initial public release, a lot of work has been made around it, and I'm pretty sure you would be surprised about what it has to offer. So, why not join us to learn more about this NoSQL database? Learn what are some real use cases in production and what are the traps and pitfalls to avoid.

Our speaker for this session will be Duyhai Doan from DataStax.

Abstract:

PART 1: “Introduction to Cassandra”

In this session, we’ll introduce Apache Cassandra, highlight its architecture, consistency and replication model to explain how the database can provide linear scalability, high availability and consistent performance. There will be a quick overview of the Cassandra data model, query language and tooling for developers

PART 2: "Cassandra real-world best practices and worst anti-patterns"

For this session, we'll show some best practices, dig into some nice use-cases seen in production but also the worst anti-patterns to avoid. There will be an interactive demo.
name: Introduction to Cassandra, best practices and anti-patterns
